unnormalised: **What are some practical ways ordinary citizens in India can improve air quality in their cities?**
normalised: **What are some practical ways ordinary citizens in India can improve air quality in their cities?**

unnormalised: Air quality is a pressing environmental concern, especially in many Indian cities. We've all seen those AQI readings – sometimes alarming, frankly. It's easy to feel helpless, but we can actually make a difference with some conscious efforts.
normalised: Air quality is a pressing environmental concern, especially in many Indian cities. We've all seen those A Q I readings – sometimes alarming, frankly. It's easy to feel helpless, but we can actually make a difference with some conscious efforts.

unnormalised: Firstly, embrace public transport whenever possible. Taking the metro or a bus instead of your own car reduces vehicle emissions. If feasible, consider carpooling with colleagues in your office like Rahul and Priya. Even cycling or walking short distances makes a huge impact.
normalised: Firstly, embrace public transport whenever possible. Taking the metro or a bus instead of your own car reduces vehicle emissions. If feasible, consider carpooling with colleagues in your office like Rahul and Priya. Even cycling or walking short distances makes a huge impact.

unnormalised: Secondly, plant trees! Participate in tree-planting drives in your locality. Trees absorb pollutants and release oxygen. NGOs like "Say Earth" organize such drives regularly in Delhi NCR. Remember the importance of greenery – recall that idyllic scene in the Bollywood movie "Swades" with the lush fields?

N G O's like "Say Earth" organize such drives regularly in Delhi N C R. Remember the importance of greenery – recall that idyllic scene in the Bollywood movie "Swades" with the lush fields?

unnormalised: Thirdly, be mindful of waste management. Proper segregation of waste helps reduce landfill fires, a major source of air pollution.
normalised: Thirdly, be mindful of waste management. Proper segregation of waste helps reduce landfill fires, a major source of air pollution.

unnormalised: Fourthly, support policies and initiatives that promote clean energy and pollution control. Voice your concerns to local representatives and support organizations working on environmental issues. IIT Kanpur's research on air quality monitoring is a great example of local initiative.
normalised: Fourthly, support policies and initiatives that promote clean energy and pollution control. Voice your concerns to local representatives and support organizations working on environmental issues. I I T Kanpur's research on air quality monitoring is a great example of local initiative.

unnormalised: Fifthly, minimize burning of any kind, including crop residue or waste materials. This is a significant contributor to air pollution, particularly during certain times of the year.
normalised: Fifthly, minimize burning of any kind, including crop residue or waste materials. This is a significant contributor to air pollution, particularly during certain times of the year.

unnormalised: These small changes in our daily lives, when adopted collectively, can contribute significantly to improving air quality for all. Let's strive for a cleaner, healthier India, one breath at a time.
normalised: These small changes in our daily lives, when adopted collectively, can contribute significantly to improving air quality for all. Let's strive for a cleaner, healthier India, one breath at a time.
